title: Kefraya
text:
Kefraya ( / <a href="ALA-LC">ALA-LC</a>: "Kifrayā") is a village in the <a href="Western%20Beqaa%20District">Western Beqaa District</a> of the <a href="Beqaa%20Governorate">Beqaa Governorate</a> in the Republic of <a href="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, approximately northwest of <a href="Joub%20Jannine">Joub Jannine</a>. The village is home to a mixed population of <a href="Sunnis">Sunnis</a> and <a href="Greek%20Catholics">Greek Catholics</a>.
Château Kefraya.
It is known for its <a href="vineyards">vineyards</a> and Château Kefraya <a href="wine">wine</a>s. Château Kefraya is the second biggest <a href="winery">winery</a> in the Beqaa Valley with land that extends up to amongst the foothills of Mount <a href="Barouk">Barouk</a>, south of the town of <a href="Chtaura">Chtaura</a>. It was established in 1951 by its owner <a href="Michel%20de%20Bustros">Michel de Bustros</a> (<a href="Bustros%20Family">Bustros Family</a>). Shares of the winery are owned by <a href="Walid%20Jumblatt">Walid Jumblatt</a>. 
Chateau Kefraya exports wines to a number of countries in America, Europe, Middle East, Asia, Oceania, and Africa.
Archaeology.
Kefraya was also once home to the <a href="Qaraoun%20culture">Qaraoun culture</a> with a <a href="Heavy%20Neolithic">Heavy Neolithic</a> <a href="archaeological%20industry">archaeological industry</a> prior to the <a href="Neolithic%20Revolution">Neolithic Revolution</a>. A very large archaeological site was discovered in the area running along both sides of the road. Good quality flint nodules were found amongst <a href="Eocene">Eocene</a> conglomerates where a Heavy Neolithic factory site was detected with a massive abundance of <a href="Levallois%20technique">Levallois</a> cores, <a href="debitage">debitage</a> and waste littering the surface of the site. Large numbers of <a href="flint">flint</a> tools were collected by workers that included a variety of scrapers on flakes, knives, <a href="axe">axe</a>s, <a href="adze">adze</a>s and a segmented <a href="sickle">sickle</a> blade. The type of flint found in the area was termed <a href="Kefraya%20flint">Kefraya flint</a>.
